course.subject: MATH
course.name: Probability
course.description: Sample spaces, conditional probability, random variables, independence, discrete and continuous distributions, expectation, correlation, moment generating function, distributions of function of random variables, law of large numbers and limit theorems.
course.prerequisites: MATH 1014 OR MATH 1020 OR MATH 1024
course.corequisites: MATH 2011 OR MATH 2023
course.exclusions: IEDA 2510 (prior to 2018-19), IEDA 2520, MATH 2431, ELEC 2600, ELEC 2600H, ISOM 3540

reviews.comment_teaching:
The teaching barely prepares you for what will come. There were far from enough examples to help you understand the content intuitively. The motivation behind many concepts or distributions were not given. This is not how a MATH course should be taught.

Moreover, we could not finish the content of course by the end of the semester. So, he crammed the untaught content into a make-up lecture during the study period, less than a week before the final.

The provided notes are also quite unhelpful... unlike most professors who upload their full notes, he uploads a skimmed down version of his notes that do not contain useful examples, proofs, etc. that he mentioned in class. Moreover, it's impossible to revise efficiently with them because they are a weird mix of MS word, screenshots of LaTeX papers or even for one chapter, just a PDF of images.

P.S. Again, if you want more convenient revision notes, look at my notes below :P

--
As for the tutorials, the first few weeks are honestly quite boring as it should just be review. However, for the later weeks make sure you read the tutorial notes as they may be useful for the final exam.
reviews.comment_grading:
GRADING SCHEME:
10% class participation (6 in total)
30% assignments (2 in total, 15% each)
60% final exam

So... YCW quite possibly has the worst grading I've seen. And, having taken some "interesting" courses (such as Yan Min's 2131, Chiang's 1014), that's saying something.

Firstly, the homeworks are easy and short (except in HW2 many people got 10 marks deduced because the instructions were unclear). And there's only two of them.

But then, he sets an insane final exam. If you look at the stats below, the median is only 16.75/70, or 23.9%. This is the lowest median I've heard of in UST. The upper quartile is 42.7%, meaning 75% of the class could not score over half. It's almost like the professor was setting everyone up to do poorly in the final.

So, if you score around 50% in the final, then great, you did better than 75% of the class. That means you will at least get B+ or A- right?

WRONG! I scored 34/70 and have an overall score of 66%, and the estimated upper quartile is 64%. Yet he still gave me a B. Such funny. I can't even imagine what grade the median score would give you, and to those people, you have my sympathy.

According to some sources, even getting +2SD, which I'm assuming means mean + 2*(upper quartile - mean) since the SD was not released, will only get you an A-. I don't doubt that nobody got A+ since the highest score on the exam was a 53/70.

I've heard there's some people who may be filing a formal complaint to the ARO. If anything happens, I'll keep this review updated.

Overall, I don't know what happened to YCW. His past reviews for this course were pretty positive, but this is not what I was expecting.

UPDATE 19/1/2023: After a formal complaint by some students to the MATH department head, my grade went from B to A-. So you can see the department agreed that the original grading was BS... I'm keeping the grade for this component as an E though as the department had to get involved.

reviews.comment_workload:
As mentioned, the workload is incredibly light. Only two easy homeworks.

But I must say, I wish there was more homework. A professor once told me that students say they feel lost without homework... and this is exactly how I felt in this course. The course is not easy, and two assignments are not enough to help you deeply understand the content.

I tried using the textbook as a source of exercises... but finding good questions is hard due to the sheer amount of exercises in the book.

reviews.author: calcguy
reviews.title: Essentially a Self-Study Course
reviews.comment_content:
Chapter 1 : Preliminary
Chapter 2 : Probability
Chapter 3 : Random Variables and Probabilty Distributions
Chapter 4 : Joint and Conditional Probability Distributions
Chapter 5 : Covariance, Correlation, and Moment Generating Functions

The content before midterm (except Chapter 1) is just a repetition of MATH2411, but with more rigorous approach. However, the content after midterm is quite hard to be understood if you do not revise them occasionally, since almost of it are new topics that require your knowledge in multivariable calculus (i.e. MATH2011 OR MATH2023), e.g. double integration.

This course will be really beneficial for those who want to take Exam P - Probability (SOA), since the exam syllabus is pretty much the same as the content covered in this course (though there are few "not so hard" topics not discussed in this course)
reviews.comment_teaching:
I personally love the way he teaches. More importantly, incomplete notes imply the need of attending the lectures. However, you could actually refer to the reference textbook for the details of each material taught in the class.

For the tutorial, it is a complete waste of time going there. I personally attend the tutorial twice, yet I did not learn anything from the tutorials.
reviews.comment_grading:
Scheme 1:
Homework : 10%
Midterm : 35%
Final : 55%

Scheme 2:
Homework : 10%
Midterm : 0%
Final : 90%

(a) For the homework, it is not that hard to actually obtain full score. First, the assignment problems are the exact replica to the problems in the previous years. Moreover, SOME of the questions are even copied from the textbook examples, so you can simply copy and paste them.

(b) For midterm exam, you have to read your lecture notes and also do the end-chapter problems (especially theoritical problems), since some of them will actually appear in the exam in the exactly same way.

(c) For the final, save at least 2 weeks to review chapter 4 and chapter 5, since it is heavily demanded in the exam. Again, doing the end-chapter problems will help preparing for your final exam.

reviews.comment_workload:
Not that much of workload for this course. Each assignment is due about 3 weeks before the deadline, so you have more than enough time to finish them and discuss with your friends. With the help of self-created formula sheet, the midterm and final exam will look less hard, though it takes some time to create the formula sheet. Just remember that concept is far more important than statements.

Just be careful that focusing on doing assignments ONLY will certainly be unhelpful towards the exams.

reviews.author: USTAsiaNo1
reviews.title: Excellent introduction to probability
reviews.comment_content:
- List of topcis

Chapter 1 : Preliminary
Chapter 2 : Probability
Chapter 3 : Random Variables and Probabilty Distributions
Chapter 4 : Joint and Conditional Probability Distributions
Chapter 5 : Covariance, Correlation, and Moment Generating Functions

- Brief comment on each chapter

> Ch1 is simply a revision of secondary school thing, n!, nCr, nPr, (a+b)^n = ..., etc
> Ch2 is basic probability, like the famous birthday problem. It is basic since it uses basic concept, not because it is easy!
> Ch3-4 is something real
1. Single-variable distribution
You will learn up to
   > 6 discrete distribution, and
   > 6 continuous distribution
You are required to learn the intuition, formula, properties (like memoryless), relationship between distribution, and distribution approximation.
2. Multivariable distribution
Besides these (1-dim) distribution, you will also learn joint distribution, like multinomial (discrete) and multi-normal (continuous)
3. Conditional distribution (single or multi-variable)
> Ch5 is something fun
It covers moment of generating function (mgf) and uniqueness of mgf per distribution
It generalizes the process like finding expectation, variance, or in general the expectation of a vector
It is hard and abstract, but prof didn't try to scare us by crazy stuff, what u learn is still the basic to this topic and, to be honest, quite fun

- Sum-up

so, main coverage:
1. Single-variable, Discrete and Continuous distribution
2. Joint distribution
3. Conditional distribution
4. Moments

reviews.author: yyubu
reviews.title: good grade course for extensional study in probability
reviews.comment_content:
Content coverage:
Chapter 1-2: probability by combinatorial analysis
Chapter 3: conditional probability and independence
Chapter 4: random variables
Chapter 5: continuous random variables
Chapter 6: jointly distributed random variables
Chapter 7: properties of expectation

Chapter 1-2 basically reviews high school probability stuff, such as combination, permutation and a few classic example questions. Very friendly for all students from different programs to fit in. Another great part is that chapters afterwards all begin with something we already learned in high school and gradually go deeper. But I would say that they are still quite understandable and fun. So generally speaking, the content is well-structured and friendly for all.

Assignments:
5 assignments accounting for 15% of the grade. each has around 17 questions( fill in blank, multiple choice)

These assignments allow you to type in answers many times( almost too many). One assignment usually takes around 3 hours( you guys definitely can do better than me Haha) , so it's important to start early and spend some time reviewing. As for difficulty, I'd say its reasonably difficult. Usually it's not sth you can't figure out but it requires precision and careful calculation. You can usually get full marks if you spend time on it.

Attendance:
Accounting for an extra 5% in total grade. It is highly recommended to attend the lecture.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The instructor ACTUALLY sent reminders to us if we hadn't finished assignments a few days before ddl. This really prompted me to fight procrastination and finished the task on time. This might be embarrassing, but it's working.

Teaching is very detailed and most of the time your question in the zoom chat box will be answered right away.

btw, 1.5 speed for zoom recording is great :)
reviews.comment_grading:
Assessment Scheme:
Two assessment scheme:
1.
15% assignments
30% mid-term
55% final

2.
15% assignments
0% mid-term( in case your can't attend midterm)
85% final

The final grade= max{ assessment 1, assessment 2} + 5% attendance

This grading scheme saved my life.

My midterm scored 0 because I sent my cheat sheet as answer during mid-term... And it was not until final exam that I found my scanner app malfunctioned. Thankfully, I scored high in final exam and got an A+. But this was just far too thrilling and risky...

The grade distribution seems not accessible, so I might just post midterm and final's score information here.

midterm:
Min: 33.   Max: 100
1st quartile: 75
Median: 87
3rd quartile: 94

final exam:
Min:0     Max:110
1st quantile: 51.75  
Median: 79
3rd quantile: 93

Overall the grading is good. In retrospect, one reason is that current exam format is very friendly. The midterm and final are all long questions involving only calculation. This requires comprehensive understanding of material and careful calculation but it's not that challenging.
reviews.comment_workload: Relatively light working load（only for online-teaching mode I guess), you spend around 3 to 4 hours a week for reviewing and practicing, and more practicing few days before exam and you will do just fine.

reviews.author: joskkk
reviews.comment_content:
Chap 1 Combinatorial analysis (~3 hours)
(i) Basic principle of counting; (ii) Permutations; (iii) Combinations;
(iv)Binomial and multinomial theorems ; (v) The number of integer solutions of equations.
• Chaps 2 and 3 Axioms, Independence and Conditional probability (~6 hours)
(i) Sample space, events and some set notations; (ii) Unions and intersection of event;
(iii) Laws of events;
(iv) Definition and properties of probability; (v) Probability of events in the sample space with
equally likely outcomes;
(vi) Conditional probability, and independence of events; (vii) total probability and Baye’s
theorem
• Chaps 4 and 5 Random variables and Probability distributions (~10.5 hours)
(i) Bernoulli and Binomial random variables; (ii)Poisson random variable and Poisson
process;
(iii) Geometric, Negative Binomial and Hypergeometric random variables; (iv) Distribution of
a function of a discrete random variable;
(v) Uniform, Exponential, Normal random variables; (vi) Normal approximation to the
Binomial and Poisson distribution; (vii) Gamma, Beta, lognormal random variables; (viii)
Distribution of a function of a continuous random variable.
• Chap 6 Joint distributions of random variables (~10 hours)
(i) Marginal pmf and Marginal pdf; (ii) Distribution of a function of two or more random
variables; (iii) Independence of random variables;
(iv) Sum of independent random variables; (v) Central limit theorem; (vi) Conditional
distributions, conditional pmf, and conditional pdf.
• Chap 7 Expectation and Moment generating functions (~5 hours)
(i) Covariance and correlation; (ii) Variance of sum of random variables; (iii) Conditional expectation and conditional variance;
(iv) Moment generating function • Chap 8 Law of large numbers (~1.5 hours)

reviews.comment_content: The content is almost the same with what the other students said. So, I will not talk too much about it. But I want to point out that Chapter 4 and Chapter 5, the last two chapters are really hard and need to use more time to study and focus on. Chapter 4 is about the two random variables, the joint pmf,pdf and marginal pmt, pdf. Those kind of different combination things. You should have basic skills on multivariable calculus so as to understand and know how to integrate the functions.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor used powerpoint and notes to teach the students. Normally, he uploads the notes to his webpage. You can find the notes and assignments there. I suggest you print out the notes since there are a lot of spaces that are empty, maybe the instructor wants the students join the lectures and write those things down by themselves. So, don't miss and lessons. Once I was sick I still got back to the school for his lesson.
reviews.comment_grading:
I don't think the grading is good. Since it is normal for students to do much better in the mid-term exam than the final exam.

In this semester, the mid-term exam just included basic probability and different distributions(Poisson, Binomial, Normal, Negative Binomial, Geometric). So, most of the students can do it well. As well as the instructor provided the formula sheet for the students and you can create your own cheat sheet at the same time, so this helped students need not to remember the distribution functions by themselves.

After the mid-term exam, as I said before, the main character will be the Two or More Random Variables. The general concepts are not difficult to understand but I think there are not enough examples to let students digest what is going on. I suggested you have to do the questions by yourself and check the solutions. Since those solutions have been provided.

As I heard that, staying at mean can get a B-/C+. Fewer students get B-, much more students get a C+. So, I don't think the grading is good.
reviews.comment_workload: I think not really hard, only 3 assignments need to be handed in. But some of the questions you can find out in the notes or past paper. So, I think one to two hours will be enough for an assignment. And usually, the instructor released the homework a month before the deadline, I believe the time should be enough for you to do it.

reviews.author: NightShade
reviews.title: Self study is vital, but oh dear, you can't skip lectures
reviews.comment_content: Rich (in proofs). Easy in the beginning. Notes are sufficient but have too many fill in the blanks. So while you're blindly copying from the board, you're wasting precious hours. If you miss the lectures you may not only have to google the difficult-to-find answers, but may also miss the in-class assignments (2% each) which should be outlawed from grading since the answer is given in the classroom (basically surprise attendance).
reviews.comment_teaching: The prof is a good person, for he easily increases your score during paper checking and sympathizes with your unfortunately humongous schedule. However, his teaching is lackluster, dispirited (since he is prone to mumbling to an audience) and limited to writing on the whiteboard that which could have simply been filled into the notes. But you don't have an option to take another prof as long as you take this course in spring.
reviews.comment_grading:
Since there is no homework enforced, if you lack the motivation to practice yourself, your grades will plummet. Naturally! But if you practice, it pays.

The mean is around 50-60% (C range)
SD is around 20
reviews.comment_workload: Extensive and heavy, only if you have never done it before and have to do it yourself. And practice proofs and derivations more than anything else. By the end, you'll realize how easy a course this was if only it had been taught better. So yea, the workload really depends on your level of logical understanding.

reviews.comment_grading:
The grading scheme:
Homework 15% (3% for each homework, everyone should get full mark besides those start late/miss the deadline like me :D)
Mock Midterm 1%
Midterm 34% (mean: 70.27, sd: 14.69)
Final 50% (mean: 68.18, sd: 17.03)

Since there are rumours about the compulsory testing in HK, professor decides to make the midterm exam optional. The grading scheme takes the higher from the following:
Scheme 1: 34% midterm + 50% final
Scheme 2: 84% final

This course is absolute grading. However, professor lower the cut-offs by 5%. I guess it is because of COVID situation and a lower mean compared to previous offerings. The new grade cut-off will be 90% for A+, and the course mean: 70% can give you an B grade. Professor claims that she gave out 30% A-range last year. I think she is also very lenient in this offering.
reviews.comment_workload:
5 Homework, you should be able to finish them all within 1 day for each one, everyone get the same set of questions.

The midterm exam being optional this year, but the difficulty is relatively low (this reflects from the high mean). It tests on the topic for basic counting, permutations and probability, also some part of the discrete R.V.s.

The final exam is not cumulative. Some of the questions basically come from the lecture notes but with some modification. Therefore, study all examples in the lecture notes will be the most important.

Knowledge in MATH2023 is applicable in the joint distribution part because you have to do double integrals and change of variables. Her notes is detailed enough to cover all the necessary techniques for this course.

Personally, I study 2 days before exam and feel ok with the exam paper, the difficulty is comparable to examples in lecture notes.

reviews.author: cdbn
reviews.comment_content:
这门课的主要内容:
midterm前 (discrete):
- permutations，combinations
- inclusion-exclusion
- multinomial theorem
- conditional probability
- independence of RV
- law of total probability
- baye’s theorem
- PDF, CDF, expectation, variance
- discrete distributions（bernoulli，binomial，poisson，geometric，negative binomial）

midterm后 (discrete + continuous):
- discrete distributions（hypergeometric，multinomial）
- continuous distributions（normal [multivariate] + normal approximation，gamma，exponential，beta，uniform，log-normal）
- distribution of function of continuous RV
- joint PDF，CDF
- conditional PDF，CDF and conditional expectation
- independence of RV (in terms of PDF)
- skewness and kurtosis
- distribution of real／vector valued function or RV
- central limit theorem
- covariance，correlation, variance of sum of RV
- moment generating function （核心部分）

乍看之下，这门课的内容有很多，但其实midterm前有很多内容是在其它课上过了的（例如COMP 2711，MATH 2343，MATH 2411），因此对于CS的童鞋，有些内容可能会学3遍。不同的是，作为统计学／概率学第一门教得比较深入的课（我不会把MATH 2411归类为统计学课，它只是一门教公式＋计算的课），从discrete到continuous到moment generating function，这门课更着重于证明（虽然有时并不太严谨），也让我对概率学有了更全面的认知。因此，强烈建议CS的童鞋们直接waive掉MATH 2411去上这门课。

教授的笔记有很多部分都是要填空的，所以建议童鞋们去上课。还有教授有时会给一些能得bonus分的in-class question，所以不上课的话就无法得到了。

希望这门课的教授会跟MATH 2411和COMP 2711的教授讨论和重整这三门课的内容，因为实在有不少重叠之处。这样就能分配更多时间到midterm后的核心内容。
